Introduction

This Castaic Lake Water Agency (CLWA) Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant (RVWTP) Risk Management Plan (RMP) addresses the 5-year update requirement for the 2004 RMP and the 2009 RVWTP Expansion improvements which will include an increase in the maximum inventory of chlorine from 16 to 30 @ 1-ton cylinders.  The previous RMP submittals occurred on June 16, 1999 and June 16, 2004.

Facility Description

The CLWA RVWTP is located at 27234 Bouquet Canyon Road in Santa Clarita, California. RVWTP is on a property covering 65 acres. RVWTP is provided State Project water stored in Castaic Lake. The plant is currently capable of treating 30 million gallons per day (mgd) of water.  The planned RVWTP Expansion will start construction in 2009 and the improvements will allow CLWA to treat 60 mgd.

Raw water is first delivered to the pre-ozone contactor where ozone is applied for pre-oxidation and pre-disinfection. Ozonated water then enters the rapid mix structure where coagulants are added. The water is then fed to up-flow clarifiers, and then to a gravity filtration system. In the final stage, filtered water is disinfected with chlorine, monitored for chlorine residual, dosed with ammonia to create chloramines and released to CLWA¿s transmission system for distribution.

Potentially hazardous chemicals that are stored and used onsite or for which storage is available include chlorine, aqueous ammonia (19%), hydrogen peroxide, diesel fuel, liquefied oxygen, and sodium hydroxide. Liquid chlorine, used for disinfection of water, is stored in one-ton cylinders. The maximum quantity of chlorine currently stored at the plant is currently 16 cylinders (32,000 pounds). When the RVWTP Expansion is complete, the maximum chlorine inventory will increase to 30 cylinders (60,000 pounds) and the chlorine will be stored in a new chlorine building. Emergency Response Procedures

CLWA Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant uses its Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to provide step-by-step procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event of an accidental release. The Safety Coordinator maintains the ERP. The key elements of CLWA¿s emergency preparedness program are as follows:

* The plant uses a combination of audible alarms and a plant loudspeaker system to alert the staff of a potential accident and to conduct in-plant communications.

* In the event of a large release, the facility would immediately contact the Los Angeles County Fire Department and evacuate to designated staging areas.

CLWA¿s Recent Steps to Improve Safety

Based on CLWA¿s dedication to process safety and the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) reviews that were conducted as part of the 2004 RMP update, CLWA has completed the following actions to reduce the likelihood or severity of potential chemical releases:

* Removed boxes and wooden pallet in chlorine storage room.

* Installed a new, ¿in-kind¿ chlorine scrubber in 2004 to replace existing unit to handle chlorine releases.

* Replaced the pressure portion of the chlorination system with vacuum design and installed polyvinyl tubing in place of copper pigtails.

* Annually replaces basic chlorine system components (ball/check valves, tubing, etc.)

* Revises operating procedures (RVWTP Operations Manual) and Emergency Action Plan periodically.

CLWA¿s Proposed Steps to Improve Safety

Based on the 2008 PHA review that was conducted as part of this 2009 RMP update, CLWA is considering the following actions to reduce the likelihood or severity of potential chemical releases:

* In accordance with Los Angeles County Fire Department recommendations, CLWA staff who are expected to use self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) personal protective equipment (PPE) will be HAZWOPER trained.
  
* Request chlorine delivery operating procedures from the CLWA chlorine supplier (i.e. Olin Chlor Alkali) and have CLWA chlorine operators review and sign a log sheet to verify their understanding.

* Keep records of proficiency tests taken as part of chlorine training.

* Schedule a compliance audit for 2011 to evaluate process safety and risk management programs and their implementation.  The most recent compliance audit occurred in November 2008.

* Require all RVWTP visitors (CLWA staff, contractors, landscapers, etc) to review a CLWA potential chemical hazards onsite and sign a log sheet to verify their understanding of onsite chemical safety issues.

Chemicals Subject to USEPA Risk Management Plan (RMP), California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Accidental Release Prevention Program

CLWA uses chlorine (CAS# 7782-50-5) at the RVWTP in quantities large enough to trigger the USEPA RMP and CalARP.  The USEPA RMP threshold quantity for chlorine is 2,500 pounds.  The CalARP threshold quantity for chlorine is 100 pounds.  The maximum quantity currently present is 16 @ 1-ton cylinders (32,000 pounds) of chlorine.  Chlorine is transported to the facility by truck and stored onsite in 1-ton cylinders.

The CLWA RVWTP also is subject to OSHA PSM regulations for all equipment and operations associated with chlorine storage and disinfection systems. The threshold quantity under PSM for chlorine is 1,500 pounds.

Accidental Releases during Past Five Years

The CLWA Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant has not had any releases during the past five years that resulted in any injuries, off-site evacuations, or property damage.

Process Safety Management Accident Prevention Program

The CLWA Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant is subject to OSHA¿s Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations for all equipment and operations associated with its chlorine system. The CLWA¿s PSM programs include the following activities to minimize the potential for an accidental release:

* Review of the design of all equipment and controls for the chlorine system to establish they are properly designed and installed.

* Updating of standard operating procedures to include specific information on safety procedures. All procedures must be reviewed and certified annually.

* Initial safety training and 3-year refresher training for all operators and maintenance staff.
